title: Welcome
text:
Welcome
This Quarto website displays the first part of my individual project for Data Analytics for Immersive Environments for Brendan Flaherty - D00285874 and explores complex SQL queries from information about interactive cinematic virtual production.
It Includes:

Part A: SQL Queries and Database Exploration
Part B: Linear Regression Analysis and Visualisation
Part C: Technology Exploration of new R Packages



 SQL 


 Linear Regression 


 Technology Exploration

Discussion
The regression model suggests that larger budgets have a slightly negative coefficient and can lead to lower success rates. The model estimates a decrease of 0.0000025. The size of the crew is associated with greater success rate but not significant and not enough evidence to support with success rate estimated to increase by 0.0662002.

title: Technology Exploration of new R Packages
text:
For this section, I have explored the creative use of R packages to visualise data from the same SQL query in three different ways.
It Includes:

Plotly: Interactive Visualisation
GGally: Explores relationship between variables
R-Graph Gallery: Extends the tidyverse and ggplot2 libraries



  ProductionID           Title Budget CrewSize      Status SuccessRate
1            1     Eclipse Run 350000        2   Completed         1.0
2            2 Starborn Legacy 500000        5 In Progress         0.5
3            3      Neon Pulse 420000        6   Completed         1.0
4            4    Echo Station 280000        3   Completed         1.0
5            5  Gravity Dreams 600000        5 In Progress         0.5
6            6   Quantum Drift 450000        2 In Progress         0.5



Interactive Visualisation with Plotly
The Plotly library allows for interactive exploration and users can see dynamic overview of budget and Success Rate








GGally
Extends ggplot2 with pairwise plots and correlation and gives an overview of the relationship between variables for exploratory data analysis











R-Graph Gallery
Extends the tidyverse and ggplot2 libraries









`summarise()` has grouped output by 'BudgetBin'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.
